hypotheses.title: UAT-10027 Campaign: Dohdoor Backdoor via DNS-over-HTTPS in Education and Healthcare
hypotheses.description: Hunt for evidence of the UAT-10027 campaign that deploys the Dohdoor backdoor in U.S. education and healthcare sectors. The campaign uses phishing to trigger PowerShell scripts that download malicious batch files and sideloaded DLLs, then exfiltrates C2 traffic via DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) through Cloudflare infrastructure to evade detection.

data_sources_needed.specific_data: PowerShell command-line logs, process creation events with parent-child relationships, DLL load events (especially sideloading), DNS query logs
tools: Sysmon (Event ID 1, 3, 7, 11), EDR (process tree, module load), Windows Event Logs (4688, 1), DNS logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS-over-HTTPS traffic to Cloudflare (1.1.1.1/1.0.0.1), anomalous DNS query patterns (long subdomains, high entropy), TLS SNI mismatches
tools: NDR, Zeek DNS logs, TLS inspection logs, SIEM with network telemetry

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Unusual PowerShell execution from user accounts in education/healthcare, lateral movement via RDP/WinRM after initial access
tools: Azure AD Sign-in Logs, Identity Protection, Sentinel

hunting_tactics.description: Identify PowerShell scripts that spawn cmd.exe or mshta.exe to execute batch files that load suspicious DLLs via sideloading.
sample_queries: EventID=1 AND (Image LIKE '%\\powershell.exe%' OR CommandLine LIKE '%powershell%') AND ParentImage LIKE '%cmd.exe%' AND Image LIKE '%rundll32.exe%' AND CommandLine LIKE '%.dll%'
Sysmon EventID=7 (Image LIKE '%\\rundll32.exe%' OR Image LIKE '%\\regsvr32.exe%') AND ImagePath LIKE '%\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\%' AND ImagePath LIKE '%.dll%'
hunting_tactics.look_for: PowerShell scripts launching rundll32/regsvr32 to load DLLs from %TEMP% or %LOCALAPPDATA%, especially with unusual command-line arguments (e.g., 'rundll32.exe .dll,EntryPoint')

hunting_tactics.description: Detect anomalous DoH traffic to Cloudflare that may indicate Dohdoor C2 communication.
sample_queries: index=netflow dest_ip IN (1.1.1.1, 1.0.0.1) AND query_type=dns AND query_length > 100 AND query_entropy > 4.5 AND query NOT LIKE '%cloudflare.com%'
index=zeek_dns query_length > 100 AND query_entropy > 4.5 AND query LIKE '%.cloudflare-dns.com%'
hunting_tactics.look_for: Long, high-entropy DNS queries to 1.1.1.1/1.0.0.1 that decode to base64-like patterns or contain embedded C2 commands

network_patterns: DNS-over-HTTPS to 1.1.1.1/1.0.0.1 with long queries (>100 chars)
HTTPS to Cloudflare IPs with non-standard SNI
other_indicators: PowerShell with -enc or -e flags followed by base64 strings
Batch files downloading from HTTP/HTTPS with suspicious extensions (.dll, .exe)

recommended_actions: Isolate affected endpoints and capture memory dumps
Block DoH traffic to non-enterprise DNS resolvers
Review PowerShell execution policies and disable script execution for non-admins
Check for lateral movement via RDP/WinRM from initial hosts
Verify if Dohdoor.dll exists in %TEMP% or %LOCALAPPDATA% paths

hypotheses.title: UNC2814/GRIDTIDE Campaign: Google Sheets-Based C2 in Telecom and Government
hypotheses.description: Hunt for the UNC2814 campaign that uses Google Sheets as a covert C2 channel to compromise telecom and government organizations. Attackers leverage SaaS API calls to hide malicious traffic in benign-looking Google Sheets interactions, making detection difficult without deep API telemetry.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Google Workspace API logs (Sheets, Drive), OAuth token usage, anomalous sheet edits, API calls to sheets.googleapis.com
tools: Google Cloud Audit Logs, Chronicle, Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps

data_sources_needed.specific_data: OAuth consent grants for Sheets API, unusual token scopes, token usage from non-standard locations
tools: Google Admin Console, Azure AD App Consent Logs, Sentinel

data_sources_needed.specific_data: PowerShell/Python scripts interacting with Sheets API, credential harvesting for Google accounts
tools: EDR, Sysmon, Google Workspace Audit Logs

hunting_tactics.description: Detect anomalous Sheets API usage that may indicate C2 communication.
sample_queries: resource.type="google_sheets" AND proto_payload.method_name="spreadsheets.values.update" AND proto_payload.request_metadata.caller_supplied_user_agent NOT LIKE '%Google%'
audit_log.proto_payload.method_name IN ('spreadsheets.values.append', 'spreadsheets.values.update') AND proto_payload.authentication_info.principal_email NOT LIKE '%@yourdomain.com%'
hunting_tactics.look_for: Non-Google user agents accessing Sheets APIs, frequent small updates to specific cells, or data written to sheets from unexpected geographic locations

hunting_tactics.description: Identify OAuth tokens granted to Sheets API with excessive permissions or used from unusual contexts.
sample_queries: audit_log.proto_payload.method_name="token.grant" AND proto_payload.authentication_info.principal_email=* AND proto_payload.request_params.scopes LIKE '%drive%' AND proto_payload.request_params.client_id NOT IN ('known-trusted-client-ids')
azuread_auditing LogonEvents WHERE AppDisplayName='Google Sheets' AND RiskState='atRisk'
hunting_tactics.look_for: OAuth tokens granted to Sheets API with Drive/Email scopes from new devices or locations, especially if combined with PowerShell execution

network_patterns: HTTPS to sheets.googleapis.com, docs.googleapis.com with unusual patterns
API calls with small payloads (1-10KB) at regular intervals
user_agent_strings: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (non-Google user agent)
other_indicators: Google API keys embedded in scripts or config files

recommended_actions: Revoke suspicious OAuth tokens and audit app permissions
Enable Google Workspace audit logging for Sheets and Drive
Implement API rate limiting and anomaly detection for Sheets API
Block non-enterprise Google API access via CASB
Review recent phishing emails targeting telecom/gov employees

hypotheses.title: ClickFix Campaign: DNS Tunneling via Nslookup for RAT Delivery
hypotheses.description: Hunt for the evolving ClickFix campaign that uses social engineering to trick users into running nslookup commands to retrieve malware payloads via DNS tunneling. This technique bypasses traditional security controls by leveraging built-in Windows tools and DNS as a covert channel.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.003 - Command Scripting: Windows Command Shell

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Command-line logs for nslookup.exe, PowerShell execution with suspicious parameters, process creation chains (e.g., cmd.exe → nslookup.exe → powershell.exe)
tools: Sysmon (Event ID 1), EDR, Windows Event Logs (4688, 1)

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS queries with unusually long subdomains, TXT record queries to suspicious domains, DNS traffic to non-standard resolvers
tools: Zeek DNS logs, SIEM with DNS analytics, NDR

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Phishing emails with fake CAPTCHA instructions, malicious links to fake update pages
tools: Email security gateway logs, SIEM email correlation

hunting_tactics.description: Detect nslookup.exe usage for DNS-based payload retrieval.
sample_queries: EventID=1 AND (Image LIKE '%\\nslookup.exe%' OR CommandLine LIKE '%nslookup%') AND CommandLine LIKE '%-q=txt%' AND CommandLine LIKE '%.com%'
Sysmon EventID=1 WHERE Image LIKE '%\\nslookup.exe%' AND CommandLine LIKE '%-q=txt%' AND CommandLine LIKE '%[a-z0-9]{30,}%'
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup.exe executed with -q=txt flag and long base64-like subdomains, especially when triggered from cmd.exe or PowerShell

hunting_tactics.description: Identify the full ClickFix chain: phishing → fake CAPTCHA → clipboard manipulation → command execution.
sample_queries: EventID=1 AND (CommandLine LIKE '%mshta%' OR CommandLine LIKE '%powershell%' OR CommandLine LIKE '%rundll32%') AND ParentCommandLine LIKE '%cmd.exe%' AND CommandLine LIKE '%clipboard%'
Sysmon EventID=1 WHERE Image LIKE '%\\powershell.exe%' AND CommandLine LIKE '%Set-Clipboard%' AND ParentImage LIKE '%\\chrome.exe%'
hunting_tactics.look_for: Clipboard manipulation followed by PowerShell/cmd execution, especially after visiting suspicious domains or clicking fake CAPTCHA links

network_patterns: DNS TXT queries to suspicious domains with long encoded payloads
HTTP/HTTPS to compromised legitimate sites serving ClickFix payloads
other_indicators: Fake CAPTCHA pages with instructions to copy/paste commands
Google Ads hijacked to promote fake Claude AI guides

recommended_actions: Block nslookup.exe from network access unless explicitly required
Disable clipboard access for non-admin processes
Audit PowerShell execution policies and block unsigned scripts
Review recent phishing campaigns targeting developers and IT staff
Monitor for nslookup.exe spawning additional processes (e.g., powershell.exe)

hypotheses.title: SmartLoader Campaign: Trojanized Oura MCP Server for StealC Infostealer
hypotheses.description: Hunt for the SmartLoader campaign that clones legitimate Oura Health Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers to distribute the StealC infostealer. Attackers create fake GitHub repositories with fake forks and contributors to appear credible, tricking developers into installing malicious packages.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials In Files
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Node.js/NPM package installations, Python package installations, process execution from development tools (VS Code, CLI)
GitHub repository clones, npm package downloads, MCP server connections
tools: GitHub Audit Logs, npm audit logs, SIEM

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Developer account logins, unusual package installation patterns, API key usage

hunting_tactics.description: Detect suspicious MCP server installations that may indicate SmartLoader activity.
sample_queries: index=github actor=* AND action=repo.clone AND repo.name LIKE '%ouramcp%' AND repo.name NOT LIKE '%oura-health%'
index=npm action=install AND package.name LIKE '%ouramcp%' AND package.version NOT IN ('known-good-versions')
hunting_tactics.look_for: Clones or installations of repositories named 'ouramcp', 'oura-mcp', or similar typosquatting names, especially from non-official sources

sample_queries: EventID=1 AND Image LIKE '%\\node.exe%' AND CommandLine LIKE '%stealc%'
Sysmon EventID=7 WHERE Image LIKE '%\\node.exe%' AND ImagePath LIKE '%\\AppData\\Roaming\\npm\\node_modules\\stealc%'
hunting_tactics.look_for: Node.js processes executing from npm modules named 'stealc', 'steal-c', or similar, especially with command-line arguments for data exfiltration

network_patterns: HTTPS to GitHub.com for repository clones
DNS queries to GitHub's IP ranges
HTTP/HTTPS to GitHub Pages for payload delivery
other_indicators: Fake GitHub forks with no commits
MCP server packages with no documentation or README

recommended_actions: Review npm package dependencies for known malicious packages (e.g., 'stealc')
Audit GitHub repository clones for typosquatting names
Block npm packages with no documentation or suspicious metadata
Monitor for Node.js processes accessing sensitive files (e.g., .env, .aws/credentials)
Verify MCP server authenticity through official Oura Health channels

hypotheses.title: Lazarus Group: Medusa Ransomware in Healthcare and Middle East Targets
hypotheses.description: Hunt for Lazarus Group activity using Medusa ransomware against healthcare organizations and Middle Eastern targets. The group has shifted toward profit-focused ransomware attacks, using Medusa as a new tool in their arsenal alongside traditional espionage tools.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Ransomware encryption patterns (file extensions, ransom notes), process injection, credential dumping
tools: EDR, Sysmon (Event ID 1, 10, 11), Windows Event Logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: C2 traffic to known Lazarus infrastructure, unusual outbound traffic to North Korea IPs
Spearphishing emails with malicious attachments (Word, Excel, PDF)

hunting_tactics.description: Detect Medusa ransomware encryption activity by monitoring for file modification patterns and ransom note creation.
sample_queries: EventID=11 AND (TargetFilename LIKE '%.encrypted' OR TargetFilename LIKE '%.medusa' OR TargetFilename LIKE '%.lock') AND ProcessName LIKE '%\\rundll32.exe%'
Sysmon EventID=11 WHERE TargetFilename LIKE '%\\$RECYCLE.BIN\\*' AND ProcessName LIKE '%\\rundll32.exe%'
hunting_tactics.look_for: Files with .encrypted, .medusa, or .lock extensions, ransom notes (README.txt, HOW_TO_DECRYPT.html), and rundll32.exe encrypting files

hunting_tactics.description: Identify known Lazarus infrastructure used in Medusa campaigns.
sample_queries: index=netflow dest_ip IN (known-lazarus-ips) OR dest_port IN (443, 80, 8080) AND dest_ip_country='KP'
index=zeek_http user_agent LIKE '%Lazarus%' OR host LIKE '%lazarus%'
hunting_tactics.look_for: Connections to known Lazarus IPs (e.g., 175.45.176.0/24), unusual outbound traffic to North Korea, or use of Lazarus user agents

network_patterns: DNS queries to suspicious domains with North Korean TLD (.kp)
other_indicators: Use of Cobalt Strike in initial access

recommended_actions: Isolate systems with encrypted files and preserve evidence
Block known Lazarus IPs and domains at the firewall
Review email logs for spearphishing campaigns targeting healthcare
Check for Cobalt Strike beacons in memory dumps
Verify if Medusa ransom notes exist on endpoints

unique_mitre_techniques: T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1059.003 - Command Scripting: Windows Command Shell
T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials In Files

top_attack_vectors: Unknown (no specific vector disclosed in article)
